lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project dialog first)
1. Set up the correct JDK version, as follows:
1. Click `Configure` > `Structure for New Projects` and then `Project Settings` > `Project` > `Project SDK`
1. If JDK 11 is listed in the drop down, select it. If it is not, click `New...` and select the directory where you installed JDK 11
1. Import the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. After the importing is complete, locate the `src/main/java/duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run duke.main()`. If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below:
* The Duke class that runs the Duke task manager program
* The main method, when run, runs the Duke Program.
* Constructor of the Deadline object which extends Task{@link Task}. It stores the description of the task as well
* as the deadline of the task, formatted in FORMATSTYLE.FULL.
* @param description the description of the Deadline task.
* @param by the date the deadline should be done by. It should follow the format "yyyy-MM-dd".
* Simply checks if the "by" String observes the format "yyyy-MM-dd".
* @param date The String which represents by when the deadline is due.
* @return True if the date String follows the format "yyyy-MM-dd".
* @throws DukeException thrown if the "by" String does not follow the specified format, or if the date is invalid
public static boolean checkDateFormat(String date) throws DukeException{
throw new DukeException("That is not a valid date!");
throw new DukeException("Please check your date! It is clearly not realistic >:(");
* The constructor for a DukeException, an exception exclusive to the Duke package.
* @param errorMessage The desired error message to be displayed.
* The constructor of the Event object which is extended from Task{@link Task}. It takes in a task description as
* well as an "at" String which represents where the event would be at.
* @param description The description of the Event object
* @param at where the event would be at
* The constructor of the Parser object. It takes in an ArrayList{@link ArrayList} which represents
* the current set of tasks. The arrayList is then converted into a TaskList object for easier manipulation of the
* Checks if Duke should carry on.
* @return True if Duke is not terminated with a Bye command, false otherwise.
* Simply returns the current set of lines. This should be called when Duke is terminated.
* Parses the input given by the users. The method checks if the user's input is a done, list, delete, bye or add
* command and executes the appropriate response. If the input is invalid, a DukeException is thrown.
* @param inputString The user input to be parsed
* @throws DukeException The exception explaining why the input was invalid
public void parse(String inputString) throws DukeException {

/** The File object with filePath as its param */
* The constructor for the Storage class.
* @param directoryPath the path to the directory containing the data.txt file.
* @param filePath the path to the data.txt file.
* Obtains the file required to begin Duke. If the files/folders are missing, they would be created in the
* specified directories. It then converts the txt file into an ArrayList{@link ArrayList} containing strings that
* represent the tasks specified in the txt file.
* It is important to know that the arrayList is not updated throughout the use of Duke. The goal of this class is
* to only process the initial data.txt file upon loading and saving a final updated copy of the txt file which has
* to be provided. Updates occur in the Parser{@link Parser} class.
* @throws IOException An exception is thrown as the file and directory paths specified might be invalid or cannot
* be found. In this case, the exception can be ignored as the method creates the directories as needed.
* Simply returns the ArrayList. Call this method only after calling processData or else you will only get an empty
* @return the ArrayList stored in the class.
* Saves into the txt file, located in the path specified when creating the storage object, a list of tasks which
* is obtained from the supplied ArrayList<String> parameter. The old txt file is overwritten as a result. Call this
* @param finalLines the list of tasks to be saved
* @throws FileNotFoundException Thrown by the PrintWriter class as there is the possibility that the file path is
* invalid. Fortunately, by calling processData first, this exception can be ignored as it is addressed in that
public void saveData(ArrayList<String> finalLines) throws FileNotFoundException {
* @param description the description of the Task item.
* Updates the Task object by setting it to be done or not yet done.
* @param check sets the status of the object to be done or not done. 1 = done, any other int is not done.
* The constructor for the TaskList object. It takes in an ArrayList<String> which would be manipulated using the
* methods in the object. It also stores the number of items in said ArrayList and the number gets updated with
* certain TaskList methods. This is to reduce the number of calls to ArrayList.size().
* @param lines The ArrayList to be stored and manipulated.
* Adds a task to the task list if the number of items is less than 100. Updates the number of items in the list
* @param task The task to be added
* Removes a task from the task list based on the index provided. Updates the number of items in the list
* @param index the index of the task to be removed.
* Changes a task in the task list based on the index provided to the task provided.
* @param index the index of the task to be replaced.
public void updateTask(String task, int index) {
* Returns the stored arrayList of tasks.
* @return the lists of tasks currently stored.
* Returns the task stored in the position provided. This method is only called after verifying that the position
* is valid, i.e not negative and not more than the number of items in the stored list. This is done in the Parser
* @param position the position of the task desired.
* @return the string representing the task desired.
* Simply returns the number of items in the stored list.
* @return the number of items in the stored list.
* Finds all tasks that contains the keyword
* @param keyword The keyword that we want our resulting tasks to have
* @return An arrayList containing the tasks that contains the keyword
* The constructor for the Todo object which extends Task{@link Task}.
* @param description simply the descriptiong of the todo object.
* The Ui class handles all of the Ui interaction with the users using its various static methods
* Introduces Duke to the users upon start up by printing an introduction.
String intro = "Hello! I'm Duke\nWhat can i do for you?\n";
* Prints out a done statement while updating the task string by swapping the cross with a tick.
* The doneTask argument must comply with the standard output string format of Duke tasks.
* @param doneTask the task that is to be marked done.
System.out.println(divider + "Nice! I have marked this task as done:");
* Prints out the tasks in numerical order based on the ArrayList param.
* The lines argument must contain Strings that comply with the standard output string format of Duke tasks.
* @param lines List of tasks to be printed.
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your list!");
* Same as listTasks() except that the message printed out is slightly different. If the ArrayList supplied is
* empty, a "no matching tasks" message would be printed.
* @param lines The list of tasks to print out.
System.out.println("Here are the matching tasks in your list!");
System.out.println("Unfortunately no tasks matches your keyword :(");
* prints out a goodbye message when users exit Duke using the goodbye command
System.out.println(divider + "Bye! See you next time!" + "\n" + divider);
* Prints out a statement confirming that a task has been deleted, as well as the number of tasks left.
* @param task The task string representing the task that was deleted.
* @param numberOfItems the remaining number of tasks.
public static void deletedTask(String task, int numberOfItems) {
System.out.println(divider + "Noted, the task has been deleted");
System.out.println("Now you have " + numberOfItems + " tasks in the list.");
* Prints out a statement confirming that a task has been added, as well as the number of task currently.
* @param task The task string representing the task that was added.
* @param numberOfItems the current number of tasks.
public static void addedTask(Task task, int numberOfItems) {
System.out.println(divider + "Got it, I've added this task:");
System.out.println("Now you have " + numberOfItems + " tasks in the list.");
System.out.println(divider + "Sorry, the list is full!\n" + divider);
* Handles DukeExceptions{@link DukeException} thrown by Duke package methods by printing them out for users to see.
* @param e The DukeException to be handled.
* Tests if the Storage class creates the necessary files and folders should they be missing.
* @throws Exception Exception is thrown if the test case fails.
throw new Exception("Directory does not exist when it should have been created");
throw new Exception("Data file not created");
throw new Exception("Default String Output is Wrong for Todo");
throw new Exception("Update Task Output is Wrong");

event project meeting /at jurong bird park
